front.performance: DEDICATION OF VOLUMES ONE AND TWO OF PLAYS FOR AN IRISH THEATRE .

body.stage: My dear Lady Gregory , I dedicate to you two volumes of plays that are in part your own .

When I was a boy I used to wander about at Rosses Point and Ballisodare listening to old songs and stories . I wrote down what I heard and made poems out of the stories or put them into the little chapters of the first edition of “ The Celtic Twilight , ” and that is how I began to write in the Irish way .

Then I went to London to make my living , and though I spent a part of every year in Ireland and tried to keep the old life in my memory by reading every country tale I could find in books or old newspapers , I began to forget the true countenance of country life . The old tales were still alive for me indeed , but with a new , strange , half unreal life , as if in a wizard 's glass , until at last , when I had finished “ The Secret Rose , ” and was half-way through “ The Wind Among the Reeds , ” a wise woman in her trance told me that my inspiration was from the moon , and that I should always live close to water , for my work was getting too full of those little jewelled thoughts that come from the sun and have no nation . I had no need to turn to my books of astrology to know that the common people are under the moon , or to Porphyry to remember the image-making power of the waters . Nor did I doubt the entire truth of what she said to me , for my head was full of fables that I had no longer the knowledge and emotion to write . Then you brought me with you to see your friends in the cottages , and to talk to old wise men on Slieve Echtge , and we gathered together , or you gathered for me , a great number of stories and traditional beliefs . You taught me to understand again , and much more perfectly than before , the true countenance of country life .

One night I had a dream almost as distinct as a vision , of a cottage where there was well-being and firelight and talk of a marriage , and into the midst of that cottage there came an old woman in a long cloak . She was Ireland herself , that Cathleen ni Hoolihan for whom so many songs have been sung and about whom so many stories have been told and for whose sake so many have gone to their death . I thought if I could write this out as a little play I could make others see my dream as I had seen it , but I could not get down out of that high window of dramatic verse , and in spite of all you had done for me I had not the country speech . One has to live among the people , like you , of whom an old man said in my hearing , “ She has been a serving-maid among us , ” before one can think the thoughts of the people and speak with their tongue . We turned my dream into the little play , “ Cathleen ni Hoolihan , ” and when we gave it to the little theatre in Dublin and found that the working people liked it , you helped me to put my other dramatic fables into speech . Some of these have already been acted , but some may not be acted for a long time , but all seem to me , though they were but a part of a summer 's work , to have more of that countenance of country life than anything I have done since I was a boy .

Paul Ruttledge , a Country Gentleman . Thomas Ruttledge , his Brother . Mrs. Thomas Ruttledge . Mr. Dowler , } Mr. Algie , } Magistrates . Colonel Lawley , } Mr. Joyce , } Mr. Green , a Stipendiary Magistrate . Sabina Silver , } Molly the Scold , } Charlie Ward , } Tinkers . Paddy Cockfight , } Tommy the Song , } Johneen , etc . } Father Jerome , } Father Aloysius , } Friars . Father Colman , } Father Bartley , } Other Friars , and a crowd of countrymen .

div.head: ACT I .

stage.stage: Scene : A lawn with croquet hoops , garden chairs and tables . Door into house at left . Gate through hedge at back . The hedge is clipped into shapes of farmyard fowl . PAUL RUTTLEDGE is clipping at the hedge in front . A table with toys on it .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: Coming out on steps .Paul , are you coming in to lunch ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: No ; you can entertain these people very well . They are your friends : you understand them .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: You might as well come in . You have been clipping at that old hedge long enough .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You need n't worry about me . I should be bored if I went in , and I do n't want to be bored more than is necessary .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: What is that creature you are clipping at now ? I can n't make it out .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , it is a Cochin China fowl , an image of some of our neighbours , like the others .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: I do n't see any likeness to anyone .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , yes there is , if you could see their minds instead of their bodies . That comb now ——

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge .Coming out on steps .Thomas , are you coming in ?

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , I 'm coming ; but Paul wo n't come .

div.stage: THOMAS RUTTLEDGE goes out .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . Oh ! this is nonsense , Paul ; you must come . All these men will think it so strange if you do n't . It is nonsense to think you will be bored . Mr. Green is talking in the most interesting way .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! I know Green 's conversation very well .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . And Mr. Joyce , your old guardian . Thomas says he was always so welcome in your father 's time , he will think it so queer .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! I know all their virtues . There 's Dowler , who puts away thousands a year in Consols , and Algie , who tells everybody all about it . Have I forgotten anybody ? Oh , yes ! Colonel Lawley , who used to lift me up by the ears , when I was a child , to see Africa . No , Georgina , I know all their virtues , but I 'm not coming in .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . I can n't imagine why you wo n't come in and be sociable .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You see I can n't . I have something to do here . I have to finish this comb . You see it is a beautiful comb ; but the wings are very short . The poor creature can n't fly .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . But can n't you finish that after lunch ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: No , I have sworn .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: She goes in .Ruttledge . Well , I am sorry . You are always doing uncomfortable things . I must go in to the others . I wish you would have come .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Who has come to gate as she disappears .Paul , you there ! that is lucky . I was just going to ask for you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Flinging clipper away , and jumping up .Oh , Father Jerome , I am delighted to see you . I have n't seen you for ever so long . Come and have a talk ; or will you have some lunch ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: No , thank you ; I will stay a minute , but I wo n't go in .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That is just as well , for you would be bored to death . There has been a meeting of magistrates in the village , and my brother has brought them all in to lunch .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I am collecting for the Monastery , and my donkey has gone lame ; I have had to put it up in the village . I thought you might be able to lend me one to go on with .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Of course , I 'm delighted to lend you that or anything else . I 'll go round to the yard with you and order it . But sit down here first . What have you been doing all this time ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Oh , we have been very busy . You know we are going to put up new buildings .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Absent-mindedly .No , I did n't know that .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Yes , our school is increasing so much we are getting a grant for technical instruction . Some of the Fathers are learning handicrafts . Father Aloysius is going to study industries in France ; but we are all busy . We are changing with the times , we are beginning to do useful things .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Useful things . I wonder what you have begun to call useful things . Do you see those marks over there on the grass ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: What marks ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Those marks over there , those little marks of scratching .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Going over to the place PAUL RUTTLEDGE has pointed out .I do n't see anything .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You are getting blind , Jerome . Ca n't you see that the poultry have been scratching there ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: No , the grass is perfectly smooth .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , the marks are there , whether you see them or not ; for Mr. Green and Mr. Dowler and Mr. Algie and the rest of them run out of their houses when nobody is looking , in their real shapes , shapes like those on my hedge . And then they begin to scratch , they scratch all together , they do n't dig but they scratch , and all the time their mouths keep going like that .

div.stage: He holds out his hand and opens and shuts his fingers like a bird 's bill .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Oh , Paul , you are making fun of me .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Of course I am only talking in parables . I think all the people I meet are like farmyard creatures , they have forgotten their freedom , their human bodies are a disguise , a pretence they keep up to deceive one another .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Sitting down .What is wrong with you ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , nothing of course . You see how happy I am . I have a good house and a good property , and my brother and his charming wife have come to look after me . You see the toys of their children here and everywhere . What should be wrong with me ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I know you too well not to see that there is something wrong with you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: There is nothing except that I have been thinking a good deal lately .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Perhaps your old dreams or visions or whatever they were have come back . They always made you restless . You ought to see more of your neighbours .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: There 's nothing interesting but human nature , and that 's in the single soul , but these neighbours of mine they think in flocks and roosts .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: You are too hard on them . They are busy men , they hav'n ' t much time for thought , I daresay .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That 's what I complain of . When I hear these people talking I always hear some organized or vested interest chirp or quack , as it does in the newspapers . Algie chirps . Even you , Jerome , though I have not found your armorial beast , are getting a little monastic ; when I have found it I will put it among the others . There is a place for it there , but the worst of it is that it will take so long getting nice and green .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I do n't know what creature you could make for me .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am not sure yet ; I think it might be a pigeon , something cooing and gentle , and always coming home to the dovecot ; not to the wild woods but to the dovecot .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I wonder what creature you yourself are like .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I daresay I am like some creature or other , for very few of us are altogether men ; but if I am , I would like to be one of the wild sort . You are right about my dreams . They have been coming back lately . Do you remember those strange ones I had at college ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Those visions of pulling something down ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , they have come back to me lately . Sometimes I dream I am pulling down my own house , and sometimes it is the whole world that I am pulling down .Standing up .I would like to have great iron claws , and to put them about the pillars , and to pull and pull till everything fell into pieces .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I do n't see what good that would do you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , yes it would . When everything was pulled down we would have more room to get drunk in , to drink contentedly out of the cup of life , out of the drunken cup of life .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That is a terribly wild thought . I hope you do n't believe all you say .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Perhaps not . I only know that I want to upset everything about me . Have you not noticed that it is a complaint many of us have in this country ? and whether it comes from love or hate I do n't know , they are so mixed together here .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I wish you would come and talk to our Superior . He has a perfect gift for giving advice .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: He gets up .Well , we 'll go to the yard now .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I have often thought you would come to the Monastery yourself in the end . You were so much the most pious of us all at school . You would be happy in a Monastery . Something is always happening there .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: As they go up the garden .I daresay , I daresay ; but I am not even sure that I am a Christian .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: They go out .Well , anyway , I wish that you would come and talk to our Superior . CHARLIE WARD and BOY enter by the path beyond the hedge and stand at gate .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: No use going up there , Johneen , it 's too grand a place , it 's a dog they might let loose on us . But I 'll tell you what , just slip round to the back door and ask do they want any cans mended .

sp.speaker: Johneen
sp.p: Let you take the rabbit then we 're after taking out of the snare . I can n't bring it round with me .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Boy goes out .Faith , you can n't . They think as bad of us taking a rabbit that was fed and minded by God as if it was of their own rearing ; give it here to me . It 's hardly it will go in my pocket , it 's as big as a hare . It 's next my skin I 'll have to put it , or it might be noticed on me .

div.stage: CHARLIE WARD is struggling to put rabbit inside his coat when PAUL RUTTLEDGE comes back .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Is there anything I can do for you ? Do you want to come in ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: I 'm a tinker by trade , your honour . I wonder is there e'er a tin can the maids in the house might want mended or any chairs to be bottomed ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: A tinker ; where do you live ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Faith , I do n't stop long in any place . I go about like the crows ; picking up my way of living like themselves .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Opening gate .Come inside here .CHARLIE WARD hesitates .Come in , you are welcome .

div.stage: Puts his hand on his shoulder . CHARLIE WARD tries to close his shirt over rabbit .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Ah , you have a rabbit there . The keeper told me he had come across some snares in my woods .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: If he did , sir , it was no snare of mine he found . This is a rabbit I bought in the town of Garreen early this morning . Sixpence I was made give for it , and to mend a tin can along with that .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Touching rabbit .It 's warm still , however . But the day is hot . Never mind ; you are quite welcome to it . I daresay you will have a cheery meal of it by the roadside ; my dinners are often tiresome enough . I often wish I could change — look here , will you change clothes with me ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Faith , I 'd swap soon enough if you were n't humbugging me . It 's I that would look well with that suit on me ! The peelers would all be touching their caps to me . You 'd see them running out for me to sign summonses for them .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: But I am not humbugging . I am in earnest .

lg.l: In earnest ! Then when I go back I 'll commit Paddy
Cockfight to prison for hitting me yesterday .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You do n't believe me , but I will explain . I 'm dead sick of this life ; I want to get away ; I want to escape — as you say , to pick up my living like the crows for a while .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: To make your escape . Oh ! that 's different .Coming closer .But what is it you did ? You do n't look like one that would be in trouble . But sometimes a gentleman gets a bit wild when he has a drop taken .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , never mind . I will explain better while we are changing . Come over here to the potting shed . Make haste , those magistrates will be coming out .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: The magistrates ! Are they after you ? Hurry on , then ! Faith , they wo n't know you with this coat .Looking at his rags .It 's a pity I did n't put on my old one coming out this morning .

div.stage: They go out through the garden . THOMAS RUTTLEDGE comes down steps from house with COLONEL LAWLEY and MR. GREEN .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . Yes , they have made me President of the County Horticultural Society . My speech was quite a success ; it was punctuated with applause . I said I looked upon the appointment not as a tribute to my own merits , but to their public spirit and to the Society , which I assured them had come to stay .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: What has become of Paul and Father Jerome ? I thought I heard their voices out here , and now they are conspicuous by their absence .

lg.l: He seems to have no friend he cares for but that
Father Jerome .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . I wish he would come more into touch with his fellows .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: What a pity he did n't go into the army . I wish he would join the militia . Every man should try to find some useful sphere of employment .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . Thomas , your brother will never come to see me , though I often ask him . He would find the best people — people worth meeting — at my house . I wonder if he would join the Horticultural Society ? I know I voice the sentiments of all the members in saying this . I spoke to a number of them at the function the other day .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: I wish he would join something . Joyce wants him to join the Masonic Lodge . It is not a right life for him to keep hanging about the place and doing nothing .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . He wo n't even come and sit on the Bench . It 's not fair to leave so much of the work to me . I ought to get all the support possible from local men .

div.stage: MRS. RUTTLEDGE comes down steps with MR. DOWLER , MR. ALGIE , and MR. JOYCE . She is walking in front .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge .To THOMAS RUTTLEDGE .Oh ! Thomas , is n't it too bad , Paul has lent the donkey to that friar . I wanted Mr. Joyce to see the children in their panniers . Do speak to him about it .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , the donkey belongs to him , and for the matter of that so does the house and the place . It would be rather hard on him not to be able to use things as he likes .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Algie . What a pleasure it must be to Paul to have you and the little ones living here . He certainly owes you a debt of gratitude . Man was not born to live alone .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . Well , I think we have done him good . He has n't done anything for years , except mope about the house and cut the bushes into those absurd shapes , and now we are trying to make him live more like other people .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: He was always inclined to be a bit of a faddist .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge .To MR. ALGIE .Do let me give you a lesson in croquet . I have learned all the new rules .To MR. JOYCE .Please bring me that basket of balls .To COLONEL LAWLEY .Will you bring me the mallets ? Yes , I am afraid he is a faddist . We have done our best for him , but he ought to be more with men .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Algie . Yes , Mr. Dowler was just saying he ought to try and be made a director of the new railway .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: The militia — the militia .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . It 's a great help to a man to belong to a Masonic Lodge .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . The Horticultural Society is in want of new members .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . Well , I wish he would join something .

div.stage: Enter PAUL RUTTLEDGE in tinker 's clothes , carrying a rabbit in his hand . CHARLIE WARD follows in PAUL 'S clothes . All stand aghast .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . Good God !

div.stage: Drops basket . COLONEL LAWLEY , who has mallets in his hand , at sight of PAUL RUTTLEDGE drops them , and stands still .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . Paul ! are you out of your mind ?

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake , Paul , do n't make such a fool of yourself .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . What on earth has happened , and who on earth is that man ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Opens gate for tinker . To CHARLIE WARD .CHARLIE WARD goes out .Wait for me , my friend , down there by the cross-road .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . Has he stolen your clothes ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! it 's all right ; I have changed clothes with him . I am going to join the tinkers .

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: To join the tinkers !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Life is getting too monotonous ; I would give it a little variety .To MR. GREEN .As you would say , it has been running in grooves .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce .To MRS. RUTTLEDGE .This is only his humbugging talk ; he never believes what he says .

div.stage: PAUL RUTTLEDGE goes towards the steps .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . Surely you are not going into the house with those clothes ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You are quite right . Thomas will go in for me .To THOMAS RUTTLEDGE .Just go to my study , will you , and bring me my despatch-box ; I want something from it before I go .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: Where are you going to ? I wish you would tell me what you are at .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: The despatch-box is on the top of the bureau .

div.stage: THOMAS RUTTLEDGE goes out .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . What does all this mean ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I will explain .Sits down on the edge of iron table .Did you never wish to be a witch , and to ride through the air on a white horse ?

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . I can n't say I ever did .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Never ? Only think of it — to ride in the darkness under the stars , to make one 's horse leap from cloud to cloud , to watch the sea glittering under one 's feet and the mountain tops going by .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: But what has this to do with the tinkers ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: As I cannot find a broomstick that will turn itself into a white horse , I am going to turn tinker .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Dowler . I suppose you have some picturesque idea about these people , but I assure you , you are quite wrong . They are nothing but poachers .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Algie . They are nothing but thieves .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . They are the worst class in the country .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , I know that ; they are quite lawless . That is what attracts me to them . I am going to be irresponsible .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . One cannot escape from responsibility by joining a set of vagabonds .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Vagabonds — that is it . I want to be a vagabond , a wanderer . As I can n't leap from cloud to cloud I want to wander from road to road . That little path there by the clipped edge goes up to the highroad . I want to go up that path and to walk along the highroad , and so on and on and on , and to know all kinds of people . Did you ever think that the roads are the only things that are endless ; that one can walk on and on and on , and never be stopped by a gate or a wall ? They are the serpent of eternity . I wonder they have never been worshipped . What are the stars beside them ? They never meet one another . The roads are the only things that are infinite . They are all endless .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . But they must stop when they come to the sea ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Ah ! you are always so wise .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . Stop talking nonsense , Paul , and throw away those filthy things .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That would be setting cleanliness before godliness . I have begun the regeneration of my soul .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Dowler . I do n't see what godliness has got to do with it .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Algie . Nor I either .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: There was a saint who said , “ I must rejoice without ceasing , although the world shudder at my joy . ” He did not think he could save his soul without it . I agree with him , and as I was discontented here , I thought it time to make a change . Like that worthy man , I must be content to shock my friends .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Dowler . But you had everything here you could want .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That 's just it . You who are so wealthy , you of all people should understand that I want to get rid of all that responsibility , answering letters and so on . It is not worth the trouble of being rich if one has to answer letters . Could you ever understand , Georgina , that one gets tired of many charming things ? There are family responsibilitiesto MR. JOYCE, but I can see that you , who were my guardian , sympathize with me in that .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . Indeed I do not .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . I should think you could be cheerful without ceasing to be a gentleman .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You are thinking of my clothes . We must feel at ease with the people we live amongst . I shall feel at ease with the great multitude in these clothes . I am beginning to be a man of the world . I am the beggarman of all the ages — I have a notion Homer wrote something about me .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Dowler . He is either making fun of us or talking great rot . I can n't listen to any more of this nonsense . I can n't see why a man with property can n't let well alone . Algie are you coming my way ?

div.stage: They both go into the house , and come out presently with umbrella and coat .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . Depend upon it , he 's going to write a book . There was a man who made quite a name for himself by sleeping in a casual ward .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! no , I 'm not going to write about it ; if one writes one can do nothing else . I am going to express myself in life .To THOMAS RUTTLEDGE who has returned with box .I hope soon to live by the work of my hands , but every trade has to be learned , and I must take something to start with .To MRS. RUTTLEDGE .Do you think you will have any kettles to mend when I come this way again ?

div.stage: He has taken box from THOMAS RUTTLEDGE and unlocked it .

sp.speaker: Thomas Ruttledge
sp.p: I can n't make head or tail of what you are at .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: What he is at is fads .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . I do n't think his motive is far to seek . He has some idea of going back to the dark ages . Rousseau had some idea of the same kind , but it did n't work .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes ; I want to go back to the dark ages .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . Do you want to lose all the world has gained since then ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: What has it gained ? I am among those who think that sin and death came into the world the day Newton eat the apple .To MRS. RUTTLEDGE , who is going to speak .I know you are going to tell me he only saw it fall . Never mind , it is all the same thing .

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge .Beginning to cry .Oh ! he is going mad !

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . I 'm afraid he is really leaving us .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Who has been looking at papers , tearing one or two , etc ., takes out a packet of notes , which he puts in his breast .I daresay this will last me long enough , Thomas . I am not robbing you of very much . Well , good-bye .Pats him gently on the shoulder .I must n't forget the rabbit , it may be my dinner to-night ; I wonder who will skin it . Good-bye , Colonel , I think I 've astonished you to-day .Slaps his shoulder .That was too hard , was it ? Forgive it , you know I 'm a common man now .Lifts his hat and goes out of gate . Closes it after him and stands with his hands on it , and speaks with the voice of a common man .Exit .Go on , live in your poultry-yard . Scratch straw and cluck and cackle at everything that you take for a fox .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce .Goes to MRS. RUTTLEDGE , who has sat down and is wiping her eyes .I am very sorry for this , for his father 's sake , but it may be as well in the end . If it comes to the worst , you and Thomas will keep up the family name better than he would have done .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Dowler . He 'll find the poor very different from what he thinks when they pick his pocket .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: To think that a magistrate should have such fads !

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Green . I venture to say you will see him here in a very different state of mind in a week .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Algie .Who has been in a brown study .He has done for himself in this world and the next . Why , he wo n't be asked to a single shoot if this is heard of .

lg.l: Here are the children ,
Georgina . Do n't say anything before the nurse .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Goes in for stick .Green . Well , I must be off .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . Just bring me out my coat , Green .

div.stage: They all prepare to go . MRS. RUTTLEDGE has gone to open gate and children come in , one in a perambulator . All gather round them admiringly .

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Joyce . Have you a kiss for godfather to-day ?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Ruttledge . The poor darlings ! I hope they will never know what has happened .

sp.speaker: Colonel Lawley
sp.p: Thank goodness , they have no nonsense in their heads . We know where we are with them .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT II .

stage.stage: Scene : By the roadside . A wall of unmortared stone in the background . Tinkers ’ encampment . Men , women , and children standing round . PAUL RUTTLEDGE standing by a fire .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: What do you mean by “ tinning ” the soldering iron ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: If the face of it is not well tinned it wo n't lift the solder . Show me here .

div.stage: Takes soldering iron from PAUL RUTTLEDGE 'S hand .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Sitting down and drawing a tin can to him .Now , let me see how you mend this hole . It seems easy . I 'm sure I will be able to learn it as well as any of you .

div.stage: Two tinkers come and stand over him .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Pointing to one of them .This , sir , is Tommy the Song . He 's the best singer we have , but the divil a much good he is only that . He 's a great warrant to snare hares . Tommy the Song . Is the gentleman going to join us ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Indeed I am , if you 'll let me . There 's nothing I 'd like better . Tommy the Song . But are you going to learn the trade ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , if you 'll teach me . I 'm sure I 'll make a good tinker . Look at that now , see how I 've stopped that hole already .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Taking the can from him and looking at it .If every can had a little hole in the middle like that , I think you would be able to mend them ; but there 's the straight hole , and the crooked hole , the round hole , the square hole , the angle hole , the bottom hole , the top hole , the side leak , the open leak , the leak-all-round , but I wo n't frighten you with the names of them all , only this I will say , that , when you 've learned to mend all the leakages in a can — and that should take you a year — you 're only in the first day of the tinker 's week . Tommy the Song . Do n't believe him . He 's only humbugging you . It 's not the hardness of the work will daunt you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Thank you . I was not believing him at all . I 'm quite sure I 'll be able to mend any can at the end of a week , but the bottoming of them will take longer . I can see that 's not so easy . When will you start to teach me that , Charlie ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: As another tinker comes up .Paddy , here 's the gentleman I was telling you about . He 's going to join us for good and all .To PAUL RUTTLEDGE .Wait till we have time and some quiet place , and he 'll show you as good a cockfight as ever you saw .A woman comes up .This is his wife ; Molly the Scold we call her ; faith , she is a better fighter than any cock he ever had in a basket ; he 'd find it hard to shut the lid on her . Molly the Scold . The gentleman seems foolish . Is he all there ?

sp.speaker: Paddy Cockfight
sp.p: Stop your chat , Molly , or I 'll hit you a welt .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Keep your tongue quiet , Molly . If the gentleman has reasons for keeping out of the way it is n't for us to be questioning him .To PAUL RUTTLEDGE .Do n't mind her , she 's cross enough , but maybe your own ladies would be cross as well if they saw their young sons dying by the roadside in a little kennel of straw under the ass-cart the way she did ; from first to last .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I suppose you have your troubles like others . But you seem cheerful enough .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: It is n't anything to fret about . Some of us go soon , and some travel the roads for their lifetime . What does it matter when we are under the nettles if it was with a short rope or a long one we were hanged ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , that is the way to take life . What does the length of our rope matter ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: We have n't time to be thinking of troubles like people that would be shut up in a house . We have the wide world before us to make our living out of . The people of the whole world are begrudging us our living , and we make it out of them for all that . When they will spread currant cakes and feather beds before us , it will be time for us to sit down and fret . Tommy the Song . It 's likely you 'll think the life too hard . Would you like to be passing by houses in the night-time , and the fire shining out of them , and you hardly given the loan of a sod to light your pipe , and the rain falling on you ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Why are the people so much against you ? Tommy the Song . We are not like themselves . It 's little we care about them or they about us . If their saint did curse us itself ——

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Stop . I wo n't have you talking about that story here . Why would they think so much of the curse of one saint , and saints so plenty ?

sp.speaker: Paddy Cockfight
sp.p: Where 's the good of a gentleman being here ? He 'll be breaking down on the road . It 's on the ass-cart he 'll be wanting to sit . Tommy the Song . Indeed , I do n't think he 'll stand the hardship .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , I 'll stand it well enough . Tommy the Song . You 're not like us that were reared to it . You were not born like us with wandering in the heart .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh yes , I have wandering in the heart . I got sick of these lighted rooms you were talking of just now .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: That might be so . It 's the dark is welcome to a man sometimes .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: The dark . Yes , I think that is what I want .Stands up .The dark , where there is nothing that is anything , and nobody that is anybody ; one can be free there , where there is nothing . Well , if you let me stay with you , I do n't think you will hear any complaints from me . Charlie Ward , Paddy , and the rest of you , I want you to understand that from this out I am one of yourselves . I 'll live as you live and do as you do .

div.stage: JOHNEEN and other children come running in .

sp.speaker: Johneen
sp.p: I was on the top of the bank and I seen a priest coming down the cross-road with his ass . It 's collecting he is . We 're going to set ourselves here to beg something from him .

sp.speaker: Another Child
sp.p: Breathlessly .And he has a whole lot of things on the ass . A whole lot of things up behind him .

sp.speaker: Another Child
sp.p: O boys , O boys , we 'll have our dealing trick out of them yet . The best way 'll be ——He suddenly catches sight of PAUL RUTTLEDGE .Whist , ye divils ye , do n't you see the new gentleman ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Speak out , boys ; do n't be afraid of me ; I 'm one of yourselves now .

sp.speaker: Child
sp.p: Oh ! but we were going to —— But I wo n't tell you .To the other children .Come away here , and we 'll not tell him what we 'll do .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: To CHARLIE WARD .What are they going to do ? They 're putting their heads together .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: They 're going to put a bush across the road , and when the friar gets down to pull it out of the way they 'll snap what they can off the ass , and away with them .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And why would n't they tell me that ? Am I not one of yourselves ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Ah ! It 's likely they 'll never trust you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: But they will soon see that I am one of themselves .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: No ; but that 's the very thing , you 're not one of ourselves . You were not born on the road , reared on the road , married on the road like us .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , it 's too late for me to be reared on the road , but I do n't see why I should n't marry on the road like you . I certainly would do it if it would make me one of you .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: It might make you one of us , there 's no doubt about that . It 's the only thing that would do it .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , find a wife for me .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Faith , you have n't far to go to find one . Paddy there will give you over his wife quick enough ; he wo n't make a hard bargain over her .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: But I am in earnest . I want to cut myself off from my old life .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Oh ! I was forgetting that .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: To MOLLY .I wonder what was it he did ? I wonder had he the misfortune to kill anybody ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Calling SABINA over .Here 's a girl should make a good wife , Sabina Silver her name is . Her father is just dead ; he did n't treat her over well .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Coming over .What is it ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: This gentleman wants to speak to you . I think he 's looking out for a wife .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Hanging her head .Do n't be humbugging me .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Indeed he 's not , Sabina .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: You 're only joking a poor girl . Sure , what would make you think of me at all ?

lg.l: Sabina , have you been always on the road with Charlie
Ward and the others ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: I have , indeed .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And you 'd make a good tinker 's wife ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: You 're joking me , but I would be a better wife for a tinker than for anyone else .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Sabina , will you marry me ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Oh ! but I 'd be afraid .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Why , Sabina ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: I 'd be afraid you 'd beat me .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: You see her father used to beat her . She 's afraid of the look of a man now .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I would not beat you , Sabina . How can you have got such an idea ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Will you promise me that you wo n't beat me ? Will you swear it to me ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Of course I will .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: To CHARLIE WARD .Will you make him swear it ? Have n't you a little book in your pack ? Bring it out and make him swear to me on it , and you 'll be my witness .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: I think , Sibby , you need not be afraid .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: What 's your name , gentleman ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: My name is Paul . Do you like it ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Then I wo n't marry you , Mr. Paul , till you swear to me upon the book that you will never beat me with any stick that you could call a stick , and that you will never strike a kick on me from behind .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Charlie , go and bring out that book to satisfy her . Of course I swear that ; it is absurd .

div.stage: CHARLIE WARD brings the book out of his pack .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: He takes book and kisses it .I swear , Sabina , that I will never strike you with any stick of any kind , and that I will never kick you . There , will that do ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: PAUL RUTTLEDGE kisses it .I misdoubt you . Kiss the book again .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: That 's all right .

sp.speaker: A Child
sp.p: Crying from a distance .He 's coming now , the priest 's coming !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Then the priest will marry us . That comes in very handy .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Scornfully .A priest marry you , indeed he 'll do nothing of the kind . I hate priests and friars . It 's unlucky to get talking to them at all . You never know what trouble you 're in for .

sp.speaker: A Child
sp.p: Coming up .That 's true , indeed . The last time I spoke to a priest it 's what he leathered me with a stick ; may the divil fly away with him .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: But somebody must marry us .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Of course . You 'll lep over the tinker 's budget the usual way . You 'll just marry her by lepping over the budget the same as the rest of us marry .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That 's all I want to know . Please marry me in whatever is your usual way . JEROME enters , leading the ass . He carries a pig 's cheek , some groceries , a string of onions , etc ., on the ass , which still has its nursery trappings . He goes up to CHARLIE WARD thinking he is PAUL RUTTLEDGE .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Paul , what are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Turning .What do you want ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Oh ! I 'm mistaken . I thought ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am here , Father Jerome , but you 're talking to the wrong man .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Good God , Paul , what has happened ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Nothing has happened that need surprise you . Do n't you remember what we talked of to-day ? You told me I was too much by myself . After you went away I thought I would make a change .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: But a change like this !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Why should you find fault with it ? I am richer now than I was then . I only lent you that donkey then , now I give him to you .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: What has brought you among such people as these ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I find them on the whole better company than the people I left a little while ago . Let me introduce you to ——

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: What can you possibly gain by coming here ? Are you going to try and teach them ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! no , I am going to learn from them .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: What can you learn from them ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: To pick up my living like the crows , and to solder tin cans . Just give me that one I mended a while ago .

div.stage: Holds it out to FATHER JEROME .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That is all nonsense .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am happy . Do not your saints put all opponents to the rout by saying they alone of all mankind are happy ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I suppose you will not compare the happiness of these people with the happiness of saints ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: There are all sorts of happiness . Some find their happiness like Thomas a Kempis , with a little book and a little cell .

sp.speaker: Paddy Cockfight
sp.p: I would wonder at anybody that could be happy in a cell .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: These men fight in their way as your saints fought , for their hand is against the world . I want the happiness of men who fight , who are hit and hit back , not the fighting of men in red coats , that formal , soon-finished fighting , but the endless battle , the endless battle . Tell me , Father Jerome , did you ever listen in the middle of the night ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Listen for what ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Did you ever , when the monastery was silent , and the dogs had stopped barking , listen till you heard music ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: What sort of music do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Not the music we hear with these earstouching his ears, but the music of Paradise .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Brother Colman once said he heard harps in the night .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Harps ! It was because he was shut in a cell he heard harps , maybe it sounds like harps in a cell . But the music I have heard sometimes is made of the continual clashing of swords . It comes rejoicing from Paradise .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: These are very wild thoughts . Tommy the Song . I often heard music in the forths . There is many of us hear it when we lie with our heads on the ground at night .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That was not the music of Paradise .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Why should they not hear that music , although it may not set them praying , but dancing .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: How can you think you will ever find happiness amongst their devils ’ mirth ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I have taken to the roads because there is a wild beast I would overtake , and these people are good snarers of beasts . They can help me .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: What kind of a wild beast is it you want ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! it 's a very terrible wild beast , with iron teeth and brazen claws that can root up spires and towers .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: It 's best not to try and overtake a beast like that , but to cross running water and leave it after you . Tommy the Song . I heard one coming after me one night ; very big and shadowy it was , and I could hear it breathing . But when it came up with me I lifted a hazel rod was in my hand , and it was gone on the moment .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: My wild beast is Laughter , the mightiest of the enemies of God . I will outrun it and make it friendly .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That is your old wild talk . Do have some sense and go back to your family .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am never going back to them . I am going to live among these people . I will marry among them .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That is nonsense ; you will soon change your mind .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! no , I wo n't ; I am taking my vows as you made yours when you entered religion . I have chosen my wife ; I am going to marry before evening .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Thank God , you will have to stop short of that , the Church will never marry you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh ! I am not going to ask the help of the Church . But I am to be married by what may be as old a ceremony as yours . What is it I am to do , Charlie ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: To lep a budget , sir .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , that is it , the budget is there by the wall .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I command you , in the name of the Holy Church and of the teaching you have received from the Church , to leave this folly , this degradation , this sin !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You forget , Jerome , that I am on the track of the wild beast , and hunters in all ages have been a bad people to preach to . When I have tamed the beast , perhaps I will bring him to your religious house to be baptized .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I will not listen to this profanity .To CHARLIE WARD .It is you who have put this madness on him as you have stolen his clothes !

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Stop your chat , ye petticoated preacher .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I think , Father Jerome , you had better be getting home . This people never gave in to the preaching of S. Patrick .

sp.speaker: Paddy Cockfight
sp.p: I 'll send you riding home with your face to the tail of the ass ! Tommy the Song . No , stop till we show you that we can make as good curses as yourself . That you may never be warm in winter or cold in summer time ——

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: That 's the chat ! Bravo ! Let him have it .

sp.speaker: Tinkers
sp.p: Be off ! be off out of this ! Molly the Scold . Now curse him , Tommy .JEROME goes out .Tommy the Song . A wide hoarseness on you — a high hanging to you on a windy day ; that shivering fever may stretch you nine times , and that the curses of the poor may be your best music , and you hiding behind the door . Molly the Scold . And you hiding behind the door , and squeezed between the hinges and the wall .

lg.l: Squeezed between the hinges and the wall .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Crying after them .Do n't harm that gentleman ; he is a friend of mine .

div.stage: He goes to the wall , and stands there silently , looking upward .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: It was grand talk , indeed : I did n't understand a word of it .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: The crows are beginning to fly home . There is a flock of them high up under that cloud . I wonder where their nests are .

lg.l: A long way off , among those big trees about Tillyra
Castle .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , I remember . I have seen them coming home there on a windy evening , tossing and whirling like the sea . They may have seen what I am looking for , they fly so far . A sailor told me once that he saw a crow three hundred miles from land , but maybe he was a liar .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Well , they fly far , anyway .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: They tell one another what they have seen , too . That is why they make so much noise . Maybe their news goes round the world .He comes towards the others .I think they have seen my wild beast , Laughter . They could tell me if he has a face smoky from the eternal fires , and wings of brass and claws of brass — claws of brass .Holds out his hands and moves them like claws .Sabina , would you like to see a beast with eyes hard and cold and blue , like sapphires ? Would you , Sabina ? Well , it 's time now for the wedding . So what shall we get for the wedding party ? What would you like , Sabina ?

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Tinkers begin to return .What do you say , Charlie ? A wedding cake and champagne . How would you like champagne ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: It might be middling .

lg.l: What would you say to a ——
One of the Boys runs in carrying a pig 's cheek . The rest of the
Tinkers return with him .

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I knew I could do it . I told you I 'd have my dealing trick out of the priest . I took a hold of this , and Johneen made a snap at the onions .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And he did n't catch you ?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: He 'd want to be a lot smarter than he is to do that .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You are a smart lad , anyway . What do you say we should have for our wedding party ?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Are you rich ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: More or less .

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I seen a whole truck full of cakes and bullseyes in the village below . Could you buy the whole of them ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Stop talking nonsense . What we want is porter .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: All right . How many public-houses are there in the village ? Tommy the Song . Twenty-four .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Is there any place we can have barrels brought to ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: There 's a shed near seems to be empty . We might go there .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Then go and order as many barrels as we can make use of to be brought there .

sp.speaker: Paddy Cockfight
sp.p: We will ; and we 'll stop till we 've drunk them out .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Taking out money .I have more money than will pay for that . Sabina , we 'll treat the whole neighbourhood in honour of our wedding . I 'll have all the public-houses thrown open , and free drinks going for a week !

sp.speaker: Tinkers
sp.p: Hurrah ! hurrah ! hurrah !

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Three cheers more , boys .

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Hurrah ! hurrah ! hurrah !
