sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: What did you say ?

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: Will he wake soon ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Yes , yes , he will wake very soon now .

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: What are they going to do now ; are they going to dance ?

sp.speaker: Third Friar
sp.p: He was too patient with him . He would have made short work of any of us if we had gone so far . First Dancer . Nam , et si ambulavero in medio umbrae mortis , Non timebo mala , quoniam tu mecum es .

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: They are singing the twenty-second Psalm . What madness to sing ! Second Dancer . Virga tua , et baculus tuus , Ipsa me consolata sunt . First Dancer . Parasti in conspectu meo mensam Adversus eos qui tribulant me . Second Dancer . Impinguasti in oleo caput meum ; Et calix meus inebrians quam praeclarus est .

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: Here is the Superior . There 'll be bad work now . SUPERIOR comes in .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Holding up his hand .Silence !

div.stage: They stop singing and dancing .

sp.speaker: First Dancer
sp.p: It 's the Superior .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Dancing Friars go out .Stop this blasphemy ! Leave the chapel at once ! I will deal with you by-and-by .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Stooping over PAUL .He has not wakened from the trance yet .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Who still remains perfectly motionless .Not yet , but he will soon awake — Paul !

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: It is hardly worth while being angry with those poor fools whose heads he has turned with his talk .Stoops and touches his hand .It is quite rigid . I will wait till he is alive again , there is no use wasting words on a dead body .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Stooping over him .His eyes are beginning to quiver . Let me be the first to speak to him . He may say some wild things when he awakes , not knowing who is before him .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: He must not preach . I must have his submission at once .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I will do all I can with him . He is most likely to listen to me . I was once his close friend .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Speak to him if you like , but entire submission is the only thing I will accept .To the other Monks .Come with me , we will leave Father Jerome here to speak to him .SUPERIOR and Friars go to the door .SUPERIOR and Friars go out .Such desecration , such blasphemy . Remember , Father Jerome , entire submission , and at once .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Where are the rest of his friends , Father Aloysius ? Bartley and Colman ought to be with him when he is like this .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: They are resting , because , when he has given his message , they may never be able to rest again .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Bending over him .My poor Paul , this will wear him out ; see how thin he has grown !

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He is hard upon his body . He does not care what happens to his body .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: He was like this when he was a boy ; some wild thought would come on him , and he would not know day from night , he would forget even to eat . It is a great pity he was so hard to himself ; it is a pity he had not always someone to look after him .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: God is taking care of him ; what could men like us do for him ? We cannot help him , it is he who helps us .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Going on his knee and taking his hand .They lift him into a chair .He is awaking . Help me to lift him up .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I will go and call the others now .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Do not let them come for a little time , I must speak to him first .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I cannot keep them away long . One cannot know when the words may be put in his mouth .

div.stage: ALOYSIUS goes out . JEROME stands by PAUL RUTTLEDGE , holding his hand .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Raising his head .Ah , you are there , Jerome . I am glad you are there . I could not get up to drive away the mouse that was eating the wax that dropped from the candles . Have you driven it away ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: It is not evening now . It is almost morning . You were on your knees praying for a great many hours , and then I think you fainted .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I do n't think I was praying . I was among people , a great many people , and it was very bright — I will remember presently .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Do not try to remember . You are tired , you must be weak , you must come and have food and rest .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I do not think I can rest . I think there is something else I have to do , I forget what it is .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I am afraid you are thinking of preaching again . You must not preach . The Superior says you must not . He is very angry ; I have never seen him so angry . He will not allow you to preach again .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Did I ever preach ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Yes . It was in the garden you got the trance last time . We found you like this , and we lifted you to the bench under the yew tree , and then you began to speak . You spoke about getting out of the body while still alive , about getting away from law and number . All the friars came to listen to you . We had never heard such preaching before , but it was very like heresy .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Getting up .Jerome , Jerome , I remember now where I was . I was in a great round place , and a great crowd of things came round me . I could n't see them very clearly for a time , but some of them struck me with their feet , hard feet like hoofs , and soft cat-like feet ; and some pecked me , and some bit me , and some clawed me . There were all sorts of beasts and birds as far as I could see .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Were they devils , Paul , were they the deadly sins ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I do n't know , but I thought , and I do n't know how the thought came to me , that they were the part of mankind that is not human ; the part that builds up the things that keep the soul from God .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: That was a terrible vision .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I struggled and I struggled with them , and they heaped themselves over me till I was unable to move hand or foot ; and that went on for a long , long time .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Crossing himself .God have mercy on us .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Then suddenly there came a bright light , and all in a minute the beasts were gone , and I saw a great many angels riding upon unicorns , white angels on white unicorns . They stood all round me , and they cried out , “ Brother Paul , go and preach ; get up and preach , Brother Paul . ” And then they laughed aloud , and the unicorns trampled the ground as though the world were already falling in pieces .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: It was only a dream . Come with me . You will forget it when you have had food and rest .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Looking at his arm .It was there one of them clawed me ; one that looked at me with great heavy eyes .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: The Superior has been here ; try and listen to me . He says you must not preach .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Great heavy eyes and hard sharp claws .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Putting his hands on his shoulders .You must awake from this . You must remember where you are . You are under rules . You must not break the rules you are under . The brothers will be coming in to hear you , you must not speak to them . The Superior has forbidden it .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Touching JEROME 'S hand .I have always been a great trouble to you .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: You must go and submit to the Superior . Go and make your submission now , for my sake . Think of what I have done for your sake . Remember how I brought you in , and answered for you when you came here . I did not tell about that wild business . I have done penance for that deceit .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , you have always been good to me , but do not ask me this . I have had other orders .

lg.l: Last time you preached the whole monastery was upset . The
Friars began to laugh suddenly in the middle of the night .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: If I have been given certain truths to tell , I must tell them at once before they slip away from me .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I cannot understand your ideas ; you tell them impossible things . Things that are against the order of nature .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I have learned that one needs a religion so wholly supernatural , that is so opposed to the order of nature that the world can never capture it .

div.stage: Some Friars come in . They carry green branches in their hands .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: They are coming . Will you stay and listen ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: I must not stay . I must not listen .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Help me over to the candles . I am weak , my knees are weak . I shall be strong when the words come . I shall be able to teach .He lights a taper at the hanging lamp and tries to light the candles with a shaking hand . JEROME takes the taper from him and lights the candles .Why are you crying , Jerome ?

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Because we that were friends are separated now . We shall never be together again .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Never again ? The love of God is a very terrible thing .

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: He goes out .I have done with meddling . I must leave you to authority now . I must tell the Superior you will not obey .

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: Father Jerome had a very dark look going out .

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: He was shut up with the Superior this morning . I wonder what they were talking about .

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: I wonder if the Superior will mind our taking the branches . They are only cut on Palm Sunday other years . What will he tell us , I wonder ? It seems as if he was going to tell us how to do some great thing . Do you think he will teach us to do cures like the friars used at Esker ?

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: Those were great cures they did there , and they were not strange men , but just the same as ourselves . I heard of a man went to them dying on a cart , and he walked twenty miles home to Burren holding the horses head .

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: Maybe we 'll be able to see visions the same as were seen at Knock . It 's a great wonder all that was seen and all that was done there .

sp.speaker: Third Friar
sp.p: I was there one time , and the whole place was full of crutches that had been thrown away by people that were cured . There was a silver crutch there some rich man from America had sent as an offering after getting his cure . Speak to him , Brother Colman . He seems to be in some sort of a dream . Ask if he is going to speak to us now .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: We are all here , Brother Paul .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: They all gather round him .Have you all been through your meditations ?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: We have all tried ; we have done our best ; but it is hard to keep our mind on the one thing for long .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: “ He ascended into heaven . ” Have you meditated upon that ? Did you reject all earthly images that came into your mind till the light began to gather ?

sp.speaker: Third Friar
sp.p: I could not fix my mind well . When I put out one thought others came rushing in .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: When I was meditating , the inside of my head suddenly became all on fire .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: While I was meditating I felt a spout of fire going up between my shoulders .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That is the way it begins . You are ready now to hear the truth . Now I can give you the message that has come to me . Stand here at either side of the altar . Brother Colman , come beside me here . Lay down your palm branches before this altar ; you have brought them as a sign that the walls are beginning to be broken up , that we are going back to the joy of the green earth .Goes up to the candles and speaks .Et calix meus inebrians quam praeclarus est . For a long time after their making men and women wandered here and there , half blind from the drunkenness of Eternity ; they had not yet forgotten that the green Earth was the Love of God , and that all Life was the Will of God , and so they wept and laughed and hated according to the impulse of their hearts .He takes up the green boughs and presses them to his breast .He remains a little while silent .They gathered the green Earth to their breasts and their lips , as I gather these boughs to mine , in what they believed would be an eternal kiss .

sp.speaker: Second Friar
sp.p: I see a light about his head .

sp.speaker: Third Friar
sp.p: I wonder if he has seen God .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: It was then that the temptation began . Not only the Serpent who goes upon his belly , but all the animal spirits that have loved things better than life , came out of their holes and began to whisper . The men and women listened to them , and because when they had lived according to the joyful Will of God in mother wit and natural kindness , they sometimes did one another an injury , they thought that it would be better to be safe than to be blessed , they made the Laws . The Laws were the first sin . They were the first mouthful of the apple , the moment man had made them he began to die ; we must put out the Laws as I put out this candle .He puts out the candle with an extinguisher , still holding the boughs with his left hand . Two orthodox Friars have come in .First Orthodox Friar . You had better go for the Superior . Second Orthodox Friar . I must stop and listen .

div.stage: The First Orthodox Friar listens for a minute or two and then goes out .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And when they had lived amidst the green Earth that is the Love of God , they were sometimes wetted by the rain , and sometimes cold and hungry , and sometimes alone from one another ; they thought it would be better to be comfortable than to be blessed . They began to build big houses and big towns . They grew wealthy and they sat chattering at their doors ; and the embrace that was to have been eternal ended , lips and hands were parted .He lets the boughs slip out of his arms .Puts out another candle .We must put out the towns as I put out this candle .

sp.speaker: A Friar
sp.p: Yes , yes , we must uproot the towns .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: But that is not all , for man created a worse thing , yes , a worse defiance against God .The Friars groan .Puts out another candle .God put holiness into everything that lives , for everything that desires is full of His Will , and everything that is beautiful is full of His Love ; but man grew timid because it had been hard to find his way amongst so much holiness , and though God had made all time holy , man said that only the day on which God rested from life was holy , and though God had made all places holy , man said , “ no place but this place that I put pillars and walls about is holy , this place where I rest from life ” ; and in this and like ways he built up the Church . We must destroy the Church , we must put it out as I put out this candle .

sp.speaker: Friars
sp.p: Clasping one another 's hands .The SUPERIOR comes in .He is right , he is right . The Church must be destroyed .

sp.speaker: First Friar
sp.p: Here is the Superior .

sp.speaker: A Friar
sp.p: He has been saying ——

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Hush ! I will hear him to the end .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That is not all . These things may be accomplished and yet nothing be accomplished . The Christian 's business is not reformation but revelation , and the only labours he can put his hand to can never be accomplished in Time . He must so live that all things shall pass away .He stands silent for a moment and then cries , lifting his hand above his head .Give me wine out of thy pitchers ; oh , God , how splendid is my cup of drunkenness . We must become blind , and deaf , and dizzy . We must get rid of everything that is not measureless eternal life . We must put out hope as I put out this candle .Puts out a candle .And memory as I put out this candle .As before .And thought , the waster of Life , as I put out this candle .As before .And at last we must put out the light of the Sun and of the Moon , and all the light of the World and the World itself .He now puts out the last candle , the chapel is very dark . The only light is the faint light of morning coming through the window .We must destroy the World ; we must destroy everything that has Law and Number , for where there is nothing , there is God .

div.stage: The SUPERIOR comes forward . One of PAUL 'S Friars makes as if to speak to him . The SUPERIOR strikes at him with the back of his hand .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: To PAUL RUTTLEDGE .Get out of this , rebel , blasphemous rebel !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Do as you like to me , but you cannot silence my thoughts . I learned them from Jesus Christ , who made a terrible joy , and sent it to overturn governments , and all settled order .

div.stage: PAUL 'S Friars rush to save him from the SUPERIOR .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: There is no need for violence . I am ready to go .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Taking his hand .I will go with you .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I will go with you too . Several other Friars . And I , and I , and I .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Whoever goes with this heretic goes straight into the pit .

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: Do not leave us behind you . Let us go with you .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Teach us ! teach us ! we will help you to teach others .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Let me go alone , the one more , the one nearer falsehood .

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: We will go with you ! We will go with you ! We must go where we can hear your voice .

sp.speaker: A Friar
sp.p: Who stands behind the SUPERIOR .God is making him speak against himself .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: No , the time has not come for you . You would be thinking of your food at midday and listening for the bells at prayer time . You have not yet heard the voices and seen the faces .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: A miracle ! God is making the heretic speak against himself . Listen to him !

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: We will not stay behind , we will go with you .

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: We cannot live without hearing you !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am led by hands that are colder than ice and harder than diamonds . They will lead me where there will be hard thoughts of me in the hearts of all that love me , and there will be a fire in my heart that will make it as bare as the wilderness .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: We will go with you . We too will take those hands that are colder than ice and harder than diamonds .

sp.speaker: Several Monks
sp.p: We too ! we too !

sp.speaker: Patrick
sp.p: Bring us to the hands that are colder than ice and harder than diamonds .

sp.speaker: Other Monks
sp.p: Pull them away ! pull them away from him !

div.stage: They are about to seize the Monks who are with PAUL RUTTLEDGE .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Going between them .Back ! back ! I will have no scuffling here . Let the devil take his children if he has a mind to . God will call His own .

div.stage: The Monks fall back . SUPERIOR goes up to altar , takes the cross from it and turns , standing on the steps .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Father Aloysius , come to me here .ALOYSIUS takes PAUL RUTTLEDGE 'S hand .Father Bartley , Father Colman .They go nearer to PAUL RUTTLEDGE .Father Patrick !A Friar comes towards him .Kneel down !FATHER PATRICK kneels .Father Clement , Father Nestor , Father James ... leave the heretic — you are on the very edge of the pit . Your shoes are growing red hot .

sp.speaker: A Friar
sp.p: He kneels .I am afraid , I am afraid .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Several Monks kneel .Kneel down ; return to your God .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: They have deserted us .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Many will forsake the truth before the world is pulled down .Stretching out his arms over his head .I pulled down my own house , now I go out to pull down the world .

sp.speaker: Superior
sp.p: Strip off those holy habits .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Taking off his habit .One by one I am plucking off the rags and tatters of the world .

div.head: ACT V .

stage.stage: Scene : Smooth level grass near the Shannon . Ecclesiastical ruins , a part of which have been roofed in . Rocky plain in the distance , with a river . FATHER COLMAN sorting some bundles of osiers .
ALOYSIUS enters with an empty bag .

lg.l: You are the first to come back Aloysius . Where is Brother
Bartley ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He parted from me at the cross roads and went on to preach at Shanaglish . He should soon be back now .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Have you anything in the bag ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Nothing .Throws the bag down .It does n't seem as if our luck was growing . We have but food enough to last till to-morrow . We have hardly that . The rats from the river got at the few potatoes I gathered from the farmers at Lisheen last week , in the corner where they were .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: This is the first day you got nothing at all . Maybe you did n't ask the right way .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I asked for alms for the sake of the love of God . But the first place where I asked it , the man of the house was giving me a handful of meal , and the woman came and called out that we were serving the devil in the name of God , and she drove me from the door .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: It is since the priests preached against us they say that . Did you go on to Lisheen . They used always to treat us well there .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I did , but I got on no better there .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: That is a wonder , after the woman that had the jaundice being cured with prayers by Brother Paul .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: That 's just it . If he did cure her , they say the two best of her husband 's bullocks died of the blackwater the next day , and he was no way thankful to us after that .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Did you try the houses along the bog road ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I did , and the children coming back from school called out after me and asked who was it did away with the widow Cloran 's cow .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: The widow Cloran 's cow ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: That was the cow that died after grazing in the ruins here .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: If it did , it was because of an old boot it picked up and ate , and that never belonged to us .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I wish we had something ourselves to eat . They should be sitting down to their dinner in the monastery now . They will be having a good dinner to-day to carry them over the fast to-morrow .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: I am thinking sometimes , Brother Paul should give more thought to us than he does . It is all very well for him , he is so taken up with his thoughts and his visions he does n't know if he is full or fasting .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He has such holy thoughts and visions no one would like to trouble him . He ought not to be in the world at all , or to do the world 's work .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: So long as he is in the world , he must give some thought to it . There must be something wrong in the way he is doing things now . I thought he would have had half Ireland with him by this time with his great preaching , but someway when he preaches to the people , they do n't seem to mind him much .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He is too far above them ; they have not education to understand him .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: They understand me well enough when I give my mind to it . But it is harder to preach now than it was in the monastery . We had something to offer then ; absolution here , and heaven after .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Is n't it enough for them to hear that the kingdom of heaven is within them , and that if they do the right meditations ——

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: What can poor people that have their own troubles on them get from a few words like that they hear at a cross road or a market , and the wind maybe blowing them away ? If we could gather them together now .... Look , Aloysius , at these sally rods ; I have a plan in my mind about them .

div.stage: He has stuck some of the rods in the ground , and begins weaving others through them .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Are you going to make baskets like you did in the monastery schools ?

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: We must make something if we are to live . But it is more than that I was thinking of ; we might coax some of the youngsters to come and learn the basket making ; it would make them take to us better if we could put them in the way of earning a few pence .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Taking up some of the osiers and beginning to twist them .That might be a good way to come at them ; they could work through the day , and at evening we could tell them how to repeat the words till the light comes inside their heads . But would Paul think well of it ? He is more for pulling down than building up .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: When I explain it to him I am sure he will think well of it ; he can n't go on for ever without anyone to listen to him .

lg.l: I suppose not , and with no way of living . But I do n't know ,
I 'm afraid he wo n't like it .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Hush ! Here he is coming .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: If one had a plan now for doing some destruction ——

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Hush ! do n't you see there is somebody with him . PAUL RUTTLEDGE comes in with CHARLIE WARD .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: This is Charlie Ward , my old friend .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: The Charlie Ward you lived on the roads with ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , when I went looking for the favour of my hard mother , Earth , he helped me . He is her good child and she loves him .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: He is welcome . How did he find you out ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I do n't know . How did you find me out , Charlie ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Oh , I did n't lose sight of you so much as you thought . I had to stop away from Gortmore a good while after we left you at the gate , but I sent Paddy Cockfight one time to get news , and he mended cans for the laundry of the monastery , and they told him you were well again , and a monk as good as the rest . But a while ago I got word there was a monk had gone near to break up the whole monastery with his talk and his piety , and I said to myself , “ That 's Paul ! ” And then I heard there was a monk had been driven out for not keeping the rules , and I said to myself , “ That 's Paul ! ” And the other day when what 's left of us came to Athlone , I heard talk of some disfrocked monks that were upsetting the whole neighbourhood , and I said , “ That 's Paul . ” To Sabina Silver I said that . “ That merry chap Paul , ” I said .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I 'm afraid you have a very bad opinion of me , Charlie . Well , maybe I earned it .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: You cannot know much of him if you have a bad opinion of him . He will be made a saint some day .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: He will , if there 's such a thing as a saint of mischief .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: A saint of mischief ? Well , why not that as well as another ? He would upset all the beehives , he would throw them into the market-place . Sit down now , Charlie , and eat a bit with us .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: You are welcome , indeed , to all we can give you , but we have not a bit of food that is worth offering you . Aloysius got nothing at all in the villages to-day , Brother Paul . The people are getting cross .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Well , sit down , anyway . The country people liked me well enough once , there was no man they liked so much as myself when I gave them drink for nothing . Did n't they , Charlie ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Oh , that was a great time . They were lying thick about the roads . I 'll be thinking of it to my dying day .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I have given them another kind of drink now .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: What sort of a drink is that ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: We have rolled a great barrel out of a cellar that is under the earth . We have rolled it right into the midst of them .He moves his hand about as if he were moving a barrel .It 's heavy , and when they have drunk what is in it , I would like to see the man that would be their master .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: That would be a great drink , but I would n't be sure that you 're in earnest .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Colman and Aloysius will tell you all about it . It was made in a good still , the barley was grown in a field that 's down under the earth .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: That 's likely enough . I often heard of places like that .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And when they have drunk from my barrel , they will break open the door , they will put law and number under their two feet ; and they will have a hot palm and a cold palm , for they will put down the moon and the sun with their two hands .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: There 's no mistake but you 're the same Paul still ; nice and plain and simple , only for your hard talk . And what about the rheumatism ? It 's hardly you got through that fit you had , and you do n't look as if much hardship would agree with you now .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He does not , indeed , and if he does n't kill himself one way he will another . Wait now till I tell you the way he is living . I do n't think he tasted bit or sup to-day , and all he had last night was a couple of dry potatoes .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Is that so ?Takes PAUL RUTTLEDGE 'S arm .You have n't much more flesh on you than a crane in moonlight . They do n't seem to have much notion of minding you here , you that were reared soft . It would be better for you to come back to us ; bad as our lodging is , there 'd be a bit in the pot for you and Sabina to care you . It 's she would give you a good welcome .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Starting up .We can mind him well enough here . I have a plan . We have n't been getting on the way we ought with the people . It 's no way to be getting on with people to be asking things of them always , they have no opinion at all of us seeing us the way we are . They have no notion of the respect they should show to Brother Paul , and the way all the Brothers used to be listening to his preaching , and the townspeople as well . And I , myself , the time I preached in Dublin ——

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Yes , indeed , Paul , think of the great crowds used to come when you preached in the Abbey church , and all the money that was gathered that time of the Mission .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , I used to like once to see all the faces looking up at me . But now all that is gone from me . Now I think it is enough to be a witness for the truth , and to think the thoughts I like . God will bring the people to me . He will make of my silence a great wind that will shatter the ships of the world .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: That is all very well , but the people are not coming .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: And more than that , they are driving us away from their doors now , Paul .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Lights his pipe .The way they do to us . But Paul was not born on the roads .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: It 's no use stopping waiting for a wind ; if we have anything to say that 's worth the people listening to , we must bring them to hear it one way or another . Now , it is what I was saying to Aloysius , we must begin teaching them to make things , they never had the chance of any instruction of the sort here .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Takes the half-made basket from COLMAN .To make things ? This sort of things ?

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Those and other things , we got a good training in the old days . And we 'll get a grant from the Technical Board . The Board pays up to four hundred pounds to some of its instructors .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Oh , then we 'll sell all the things we make . I 'm sure we 'll get a market for them .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , I understand ; you will sell them . And what about the dividing of the money ? You will need to make laws about that .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Of course ; we will have to make rules , and to pay according to work .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , we will grow quite rich in time . What are we to do then ? we can n't go on living in this ruin ?

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Of course not . We 'll build workshops and houses for those who come to work from a distance , good houses , slated , not thatched .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Turning to ALOYSIUS and CHARLIE WARD .Yes , you see his plan . To gather the people together , to build houses for them ; to make them rich too , and to keep their money safe . And the Kingdom of God too ? What about that ?

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Oh , I 'm just coming to that . They will think so much more of our teaching when we have got them under our influence by other things . Of course we will teach them their meditations , and give them a regular religious life . We must settle out some little place for them to pray in — there 's a high gable over there where we could hang a bell ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh yes , I understand . You would weave them together like thisweaves the osiers in and out, you would add one thing to another , laws and money and church and bells , till you had got everything back again that you have escaped from . But it is my business to tear things asunder like thistears pieces from the basket, and this , and this ——

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I told him you 'd never agree to it . He ought to have known that himself .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: We must have something to offer the people .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You say that because you got nothing to-day . Aloysius has got nothing in his sack .Taking sack and turning it upside down .It is quite empty . Every religious teacher before me has offered something to his followers , but I offer them nothing .Plunging his arm down into the sack .He walks up and down muttering .My sack is quite empty . I will never dip my hand into nature 's full sack of illusions ; I am tired of that old conjuring bag .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: To COLMAN .You may as well give up trying to settle him down to anything . He was a tinker once , and he 'll be a tinker always ; he has got the wandering into his blood . Will you come back to the roads , Paul , to your old friends and to Sabina ?

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Sitting down beside him .Ah , my old friends , they were very kind to me ; but these friends too are very kind to me .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Well , come and see them anyway ; they 'll be glad to see you , those that are left of us .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Those that are left of you ? Where are the others ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Some are dead , and some are jailed , and some are on the roads here and there . Sabina is with us always , and Johneen is a great hand with the tools now , but Tommy the Song ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Oh , Tommy the Song , does he pray still ? He was beginning to pray . Did he ever get an answer ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Well , I do n't know about an answer , but I believe he heard something one night beside an old thorn tree , some sort of a voice it was .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: A voice ? What did it say to him ? Did he see anything ? We have learned too much , our minds are like troubled water — we get nothing but broken images . He who knew nothing may have seen all . Is he praying still ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: If he is , it 's in Galway gaol he 's praying , with or without a thorn tree .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Did he tell no one what the voice said to him ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: He did not , unless he might have told Johneen or some other one .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Gets up .I will go with you and see them .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: To ALOYSIUS , with whom he has been whispering .Take care , but if he goes back to his old friends , he 'll stop with them and leave us .

lg.stage: Putting his hand on PAUL RUTTLEDGE 'S arm .
lg.l: Do n't go ,
Brother Paul , till I talk to you awhile .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Do you want me ? Well , Charlie , I will stay here , I wo n't go ; but bring all the rest to see me , I want to ask them about that vision .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Exit .I 'll bring one of them , anyway .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Brother Paul , it is what I am thinking ; now the tinkers have come back to you , you could begin to gather a sort of an army ; you can n't fight your battle without an army . They could call to the other tinkers , and the tramps and the beggars , and the sieve-makers and all the wandering people . It would be a great army .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , that would be a great army , a great wandering army .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: The people would be afraid to refuse us then ; we would march on ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , we could march on . We could march on the towns , and we could break up all settled order ; we could bring back the old joyful , dangerous , individual life . We would have banners , we would each have a banner , banners with angels upon them — we will march upon the world with banners ——

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: We would not be in want of food then , we could take all we wanted .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: We could take all we wanted , we would be too many to put in gaol ; all the people would join us in the end ; you would be able to persuade them all , Brother Paul , you would be their leader ; we would make great stores of food ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: We will have one great banner that will go in front , it will take two men to carry it , and on it we will have Laughter , with his iron claws and his wings of brass and his eyes like sapphires ——

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: That will be the banner for the front , we will have different troops , we will have captains to organize them , to give them orders ——

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Standing up .To organize ? That is to bring in law and number ? Organize — organize — that is how all the mischief has been done . I was forgetting , we cannot destroy the world with armies , it is inside our minds that it must be destroyed , it must be consumed in a moment inside our minds . God will accomplish his last judgment , first in one man 's mind and then in another . He is always planning last judgments . And yet it takes a long time , and that is why he laments in the wind and in the reeds and in the cries of the curlews .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: I think we had better go down to the river and see are there any eels on the lines we set . We must find something for supper . It is near sunset ; see how the crows are flying home .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Looking up .The crows are my darlings ! I like their harsh merriment better than those sad cries of the wind and the rushes . Look at them , they are tossing about like witches , tossing about on the wind , drunk with the wind .

lg.l: Well , I 'll go look at the lines , anyhow . Put turf on the fire ,
Aloysius ; Bartley should soon be home from Shanaglish .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: I wonder why he is n't home by this . I 'm uneasy till I see him , after the way the people treated me to-day .Shades his eyes to look out .Here he is ! He 's running !

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Coming over to him .He is running hard ! He must be in some danger ——

div.stage: Enter BARTLEY out of breath .

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: Run , run , come away , there 's not a minute to lose .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: What is the matter ? what has happened ?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: The people are coming up the road ! They attacked me in the market ! They followed me , they are on the road . I slipped away across the fields . Run , run !

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: What is it ? What are they going to do to us ?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: He runs out .You would know that if you saw them ! They have stones and sticks . Raging they are , and calling for our lives . They say we brought witchcraft and ill-luck on the place ! Come to the boat , it 's in the rushes ; they wo n't see us , we 'll get to the island . Hurry , hurry !

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Come , Brother Paul , hurry , hurry !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I am going to stay .

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.p: They will kill us if we stay ! Brother Colman said they have stones and sticks ; I think I hear them !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: You are afraid because you have been shut up so long . I am not afraid because I have lived upon the roads , where one is ready for anything that may happen . One has to learn that , like any other thing . I will stay .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: He wants the crown !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Where is Bartley ?

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: He is gone . Come , you must go too , we can n't leave you here . You have too much to do to throw your life away , we have all too much to do .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: No , no . There is nothing to do ; I am going to stay .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Takes his hand .I will stay with you .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: A great shout outside .Death is the last adventure , the first perfect joy , for at death the soul comes into possession of itself , and returns to the joy that made it .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Seizing ALOYSIUS .Drags ALOYSIUS away .Come , come , Aloysius ! come , Paul ! We have n't a moment , here they are .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Good-bye , Aloysius , good-bye , Colman . Keep a pick going at the foundations of the world .COLMAN and ALOYSIUS run on .One of the Mob outside . They are here in the ruins !

sp.speaker: Another Voice
sp.p: This way ! This way !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I will not go . I have a little reason for staying , but no reason is too little to be the foundation of martyrdom . People have been martyred for all kinds of reasons , and my reason that is not worth a rush will do as well as any other .Looks round .Ah ! they are gone . A little reason , a little reason . I have entered into the second freedom — the irresponsibility of the saints . Sings . Parasti in conspectu meo mensam Adversus eos qui tribulant me . Impinguasti in oleo caput meum , Et calix meus inebrians quam praeclarus est .People rush in with sticks uplifted .One of the Mob . Where are the heretics ?

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: We 'll make an end of their witchcraft !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Here is the worst of them !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Give me back my cattle you put the sickness on !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: We 'll have no witchcraft here ! Drive away the unfrocked priest !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: Make an end of him when we have the chance !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Yes , make an end of me . I have tried hard to live a good life ; give me a good death now . One of the Crowd . Quick , do n't give him time to put the evil eye on us !

div.stage: They rush at him . His hands are seen swaying about above the crowd .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: I go to the invisible heart of flame ! One of the Crowd . Throw him there now ! Where are the others ?

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: They must be among the rocks .

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: They are not ; they are gone down the road !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: I tell you it 's in the rocks they are ! It 's in the rocks they 're hiding !

sp.speaker: Another
sp.p: They are not ; they could n't run in the rocks ; they 're running down the road .

sp.speaker: Several Voices
sp.p: They 're on the road ; they 're on the road .

div.stage: They all rush out , leaving PAUL RUTTLEDGE lying on the ground . It grows darker . FATHERS COLMAN and ALOYSIUS creep up .

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: Paul , Paul , come ; we have still time to get to the boat .

sp.speaker: Aloysius
sp.p: Oh ! they have killed him ; there is a wound in his neck ! Oh ! he has been the first of us to get the crown !

sp.speaker: Colman
sp.p: There are voices ! They must be coming back ! Come to the boat , maybe we can bury him to-morrow !

div.stage: They go out . PAUL RUTTLEDGE half rises and sinks back .
Enter CHARLIE WARD and SABINA SILVER .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: They have done for him . I thought they would .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: Oh , Paul , I never thought to find you like this ! He 's not dead ; he 'll come round yet .

lg.stage: Opens his shirt and puts in his hand on his heart .
lg.l: Paul !

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: Ah ! Charlie , give me the soldering iron — no , bring me the lap anvil — I 'm as good a tinker as any of you .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: He thinks he 's back on the roads with us ! He is done for .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: I knew he 'd have to come back to me to die after all ; it 's a lonesome thing to die among strangers .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: That is right , that is right , take me up in your brazen claws . But no — no — I will not go out beyond Saturn into the dark . Take me down — down to that field under the earth , under the roots of the grave .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: I do n't know what he is saying . I never could understand his talk .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: O plunge me into the wine barrel , into the wine barrel of God .

lg.l: Wo n't you speak to me , Paul ? Do n't you know me ? I am
Sibby ; do n't you remember me , Sibby , your wife ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: He sees you now ; I think he knows you .

div.stage: PAUL RUTTLEDGE has raised himself on his elbow and is looking at SABINA SILVER .

sp.speaker: Sabina Silver
sp.p: He knows me . I was sure he would know me .

sp.speaker: Paul Ruttledge
sp.p: He sinks down again .Colman , Colman , remember always where there is nothing there is God . One of the Crowd .Coming back with two or three others .I knew they must be in the rocks .

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: Well , he 's gone ! There 'll soon be none of us left at all . And I never knew what it was he did that brought him to us .

lg.l: Oh , Paul , Paul !
lg.stage: Begins to keen very low , swaying herself to and fro .
lg.l: One of the Crowd .
Was he a friend of yours ?

sp.speaker: Charlie Ward
sp.p: He was , indeed . I must do what I can for him now . One of the Crowd . That 's natural , that 's natural . It 's a pity they did it . They 'd best have left him alone . We 'd best be going back to the town .SABINA SILVER raises the keen louder . The Strangers and CHARLIE WARD take off their hats .CHISWICK PRESS : PRINTED BY CHARLES WHITTINGHAM AND CO. TOOKS COURT , CHANCERY LANE , LONDON .
